title: overnight-closure-section-a1-east-lothian-next-week
story: Carriageway repairs are planned for the westbound section of the road at Old Craighall Junction on Friday, February .The work will take place between pm and .am the following day.Traffic will be erted off the A at Old Craighall Junction via the westbound off-slip road, then back on again via the westbound on-slip road between those times.Tommy Deans, BEAR Scotland’s network manager for the south east, said: “A carriageway closure is necessary to allow us to complete these repairs safely however, we don’t expect these works to cause any signicant delays to traffic as the ersion is very short.”The work is weather dependent and could be postponed due to adverse weather conditions.For more information, go to trafficscotland.org

title: tranent-man-burst-home-new-years-day-brandished-bottle
story: David Thomson entered the home at Morrison Avenue uninvited and began shouting and swearing at the occupants.Thomson then wielded the bottle and issued threats of violence during the incident.The -year-old was subsequently traced by police to his home at the town’s Young Avenue, where he proceeded to assault one officer by attempting to headbutt him.Thomson pleaded guilty to the two offences when he appeared at Edinburgh Sherf Court last Tuesday.Sentence on Thomson was deferred to next month for the preparation of social work reports.

title: last-chance-residents-say-new-transport-strategy-south-east-scotland
story: The South East of Scotland Transport Partnershipis encouraging people to submit their views and help shape the region’s transport strategy.The draft strategy includes transport policies for eight statutory local authorities: City of Edinburgh, Clackmannanshire, East Lothian, Falkirk, Fe, Midlothian, Scottish Borders and West Lothian.It sets out a framework for how transport and mobility will be provided, developed and improved in the region to make it more sustainable and economically active for the next  years and beyond.Gordon Edgar, chairperson of SEStran, said: “Transport affects how all of us live our daily lives, from where we choose to live and work, how we take children to school or visit the cinema, where we can get to easilywe are disabled and how we’ll get around as we get older.“We want to hear from as many people as possible to ensure our policies for the south-east of Scotland meet their needs and address their concerns.“Whether it’s better connections for rural areas, charging points for electric vehicles, safer cycling routes or more frequent and affordable bus and rail services, we want to hear how people from each of the local authorities feel about our proposals.“The pandemic changed how we work and travel, but we must prepare our transport system for the new normal and a net zero future.”The consultation closes at pm tomorrowand for more information go to sestran.gov.uk

title: hopes-new-mine-water-treatment-scheme-improve-water-quality-esk
story: The organisation held two online sessions recently to highlight the project, amid concern by Musselburgh and District Angling Clubabout the issue of mine water discharge, fearing it was having “a negative effect on the fish and invertebrate communities in the South Esk”.These concerns predate the recent pollution incident in the River Esk last month.Residents who attended the Coal Authority sessions heard more details about the plans for the treatment scheme at Dalkeith, which will remove iron and manganese from water flowing from a historical drainage tunnel adjacent to Newmills Road, known locally as Junkies Adit.The tunnel is linked tothe extensive underground coal mine workings in the Midlothian area.In recent years, the amount of mine water discharging from Junkies Adit has been increasing and the water quality has been deteriorating, the Coal Authority said.The organisation explained that the water affected was visibly orange, which was a result of naturally occurring iron dissolving in the mine water underground, which then became solid as it mixed with air and settled out of the water.In recent years, the discolouration has become more visible further downstream and could affect the river’s ecologyleft untreated, the Coal Authority added.The Coal Authority has been working with the Scottish Environment Protection Agencyand other partners to monitor the problem and develop a solution.Details for planning approval will be submitted shortly, with a view to starting the main construction later this year.More detailed design work will be done in the coming months to develop the scheme, and residents and stakeholders will have the chance to provide feedback as the designs progress.John Batty, Coal Authority project manager, said: “I think a lot of residents are keen to see this project progress as the river is so visibly orange as a result of the mine water, and the negative impact on the wildle and ecology is widely known.“The mine workings are complex so it has taken many years to get to this point.“We have been working to carry out studies and investigations, evaluate potential solutions and establish water quality by taking water samples on a regular basis through the challenges of the pandemic.“We have undertaken research using a test treatment scheme on site last spring that provided a large amount of information to feed into the designs.”Paul Butler, SEPA mining sector lead, said: “We are pleased that the progress we have made together has enabled the Coal Authority to provide information on the proposals for a new mine water treatment scheme at the site of Junkies Adit.”Colin Beattie, MSP for Midlothian North and Musselburgh, said: “I think it is important that the public are involved with the process and it is vital public engagement continues as the scheme progresses.“I look forward to seeing the next stages of the treatment scheme and working with the Coal Authority, SEPA and the local community on this project.”Steven Dalgleish, of MDAA, said: “No faulting the Coal Authority’s commitment to the cause but the association remains gravely concerned that funding may not appear for this project.“From some of our own research, it seems that this may remain an issue for over  years, leaving the South Esk between Dalkeith and its junction with the North Esk effectively dead and useless as the main salmon and sea trout spawning bed area it once was.”

title: day-today-prestonpans-shut-due-covid-energy-price-rises
story: Thanks from the East Lothian community have been shared across social media following the news that Day-Today – also know locally as Ashiq’s – is to close.A number of factors have contributed to owner Ferhan Ashiq’s decision to close his Redburn Road shop for good on February .Ferhan told the Courier that “the writing on the wall” came when Covid struck the county two years ago.This coincided with a serious burn injury to Ferhan and we Hira’s youngest son which put “stress on the business, with hours reduced to take care of him”.Additionally, Ferhan confirmed that the Day-Today store was also facing a huge surge in electric costs – a rise from £, per year to £, – which he said was an “insurmountable” price, putting the business in an “untenable situation”.He added: “With the costs of goods rising as it was, in good conscience could I really be asking the people of Prestonpans to be paying more for their products “I saw the writing on the wall – their own energy pricing will be going up and,anything, they will be needing to make their money go as far as possible, so we as a family decided we will leave before we are pushed.”Energy price rises for homes and businesses will continue after Ofgem announced that average energy bills will increase by £ from April – a rise of  per cent.Pandemic isolation rules put further pressure on staff and the Ashiq family.Ferhan added: “Running a store of that size is quite an undertaking: you end up working -hour days, seven days a week for three years, no holidays, no breaks.“Isolation measures put pressure on staff members covering other shts and working much harder.”Thanking the Prestonpans community, the shop owner said: “Our family is so thankful to everyone who helped us achieve what we have in Prestonpans for the last  years.“This business put myself and my sister through education and we both went to university off the back of it, and that could never have happenedthe community hadn’t shopped in our store.“I went to school with a lot of customers and I’m watching their kids grow up and become friends with my kids.”It has been confirmed that Day-Today has been sold and will “never be a convenience store again” – the new owner and business will not be revealed until March .The Ashiq family plans to stay in Prestonpans for the foreseeable future, while the family’s Levenhall Village Store in Musselburgh will remain open.Ferhan said: “I am looking to devote more time to my lovely we Hira, who has stood by me all these years throughout all the hardships, and my young children Harris, Niall and Daniel.”The alleged theft from the premises was reported to police, who are understood to be investigating the matter.

title: east-lothian-council-leader-norman-hampshire-standing-re-election
story: Norman Hampshire is Labour’s candidate for the Dunbar and East Linton ward in May’s East Lothian Council elections.The dad-of-three has been a member of the local authority in East Lothian for more than  years.He was first elected in  but lost his seat to Stephen Bunyan, former Dunbar Community Council chairman and teacher at Dunbar Grammar School, four years later.Mr Hampshire, who lives in Dunbar with his we, was re-elected in  and has been involved with the council ever since.He became depute leader in May  and succeeded his colleague Willie Innes, who died last year, as council leader.Mr Hampshire, who is the council’s spokesman for the environment and chairman of the planning committee, said: “I am proud to have had the honour of representing Dunbar, the town where I was born and have always lived, for over  years.“I have always sought to stand up for its interests and those of the whole ward, and serve my constituents to the very best of my ability.“I have a very positive record on which to seek re-election at the election in May.“I have played a leading role in an administration which has shown strong leadership during one of the most dficult periods we have faced in living memory.”Mr Hampshire highlighted the dficulties facing the local authority in the face of the coronavirus pandemic and challenging financial circumstances.He said: “These key issues – protecting services, supporting communities and boosting the economy – will continue to be at the heart of the manesto that we present to voters in May.“I hope people in this ward and across East Lothian will put their faith in me and my Labour colleagues to continue our work helping make East Lothian the best place to live, work, visit and play.”Mr Hampshire is the second candidate confirmed for the Dunbar and East Linton ward, which also covers villages including Stenton, Spott and Innerwick.David Mumford retired as rector of the Scottish Episcopal Church in Brechin in . Now living in Innerwick, he will represent the Greens during the election.Already, Labour has confirmed Provost John McMillan and Councillor Shamin Akhtar, who represent the Haddington and Lammermuir ward, and Councillors Colin McGinn and Fiona Dugdale, who represent the Tranent, Wallyford and Macmerry ward, are standing for re-election.Meanwhile, recently elected Colin Yorkston is also aiming to retain his seat in the Preston Seton Gosford ward for Labour.The Conservatives have confirmed that Councillor Jeremy Findlay is hoping to retain his seat in the North Berwick Coastal ward and could be joined by Judy Lockhart-Hunter, the current chairperson of North Berwick Community Council.The Conservatives have also confirmed George McGuire as their candidate for the Haddington and Lammermuir ward.The Scottish Green Party has announced Shona McIntosh , Tim Porteus , Jackie Swailesand Jacq Cottrellas candidates in addition to Mr Mumford.Stuart Crawford has been confirmed as the Liberal Democrats candidate for the Haddington and Lammermuir ward.Labour, the Conservatives and SNP have all also confirmed that two of their sitting councillors will be stepping down.Jim Goodfellowand Fiona ODonnell are not seeking re-election in May for Labour, while Jane Hendersonand Craig Hoy– who was elected as a South Scotland MSP last year – are stepping down for the Conservatives.Finally, SNP Group leader Stuart Currieand Paul McLennan– who was elected as East Lothian MSP last May – are also standing down.

title: driving-ban-drink-driver-pulled-longniddry
story: Oliver Moss, of College Way, was pulled over by police officers at Main Street in Longniddry on December  last year.Moss gave officers a roadside breath test reading of mg of alcohol in ml of breath.The legal limit is just mg.The -year-old appeared in the dock at Edinburgh Sherf Court last Tuesday, where he was banned from driving for  months.Sherf Peter McCormack also imposed a community payback order and told Moss he must complete  hours of unpaid work in the community

title: nungate-gala-back-celebrate-anniversary
story: Liz McDougall, chairwoman of the Nungate Gala, was delighted to see the eventfor the first time since .She said: “This is the Nungate Gala, this is tradition and, although it is the Nungate Gala, the whole town is more than welcome to join us.”The event has been pencilled in for August , with preparations under way to create the gala court.Nomination forms are available from the Adult Training Centre, with the only stipulation being that youngsters must be from the Nungate.The royal court will then be revealed in April.Ahead of the annual celebrations, the organisers are holding weekly bingo sessions in the Nungate Hall, starting on Thursday at .pm.Coronavirus restrictions mean the hall will not be at full capacity, with  spaces available for players.Mrs McDougall told the Courier that she hoped people would attend on alternate weeks to allow those who missed out in the first week to come along.Ward councillor Tom Trotter was equally pleased to see the event ing.He said: “I was there when it restarted the first time and, hopefully, I can get involved again.“It is certainly good news because it has been a big miss for the last couple of years.”

title: hamish-mcmenemy-scaling-north-berwick-law-charity
story: Hamish McMenemy, , who has ADHD , is taking on the challenge to raise money for CAMHS .Hamish, of Lady Jane Road, got the idea when he climbed the Law with his friends, and told his mum Jane he wanted to climb it for charity.Jane said: “He was wanting to do something for charity we mentioned CAMHS and he said: ‘Let’s do something for that.’”He and friends from his primary six class will now challenge themselves to climb the Law every day in March to raise as much cash as possible. and friends ready to tackle the Law" alt"East Lothian Courier: Hamish McMenemyand friends ready to tackle the Law" class"editor-image"Hamish McMenemyand friends ready to tackle the Law CAMHS is an NHS-run service that helps treat young people with a iety of challenges.Mental health treatment has suffered during the pandemic and many children have struggled to be referred and diagnosed, said Hamish’s mum.Jane said: “It was an absolute fight to get a referral for Hamish, as it is for everybody. I have spoken to so many parents who have kids and such a massive backlog of waiting to be seen.“Hamish was diagnosed the day before lockdown, in March , so we were lucky to have got through that.”Many children in the county remain undiagnosed and unable to receive treatment as a result of the added strain on the NHS caused by Covid, Jane added.Tracey McKigen, services director of Royal Edinburgh and Associated Services for NHS Lothian, said: “We’re very grateful that Hamish has chosen CAMHS.“We’ll ensure the money he raises contributes to supporting children and young people, and their families, and we wish him the absolute best of luck.”A JustGiving page for donations to Hamish is due to be set up.

title: floral-display-created-within-boat-seafront
story: The new flower bed will be planted up in late May early June – featuring geraniums, begonias and dahlias – by staff from East Lothian Council’s amenity services department “within existing resources”.The boat is an International Laser Class vessel, used in everything from teaching and club racing to the Olympics.Called Bianca, it was gted to the community display by Fisherrow Yacht Club, which had sailed it for a number of years.Katie Swann, Fisherrow Harbour  Seafront Association’s volunteer seafront manager, said: “The team at East Lothian Council always do us proud with their coastal planting schemes in Musselburgh, and we’re excited to see how this one takes shape.“A member of the Fisherrow Yacht Club donated a dinghy and, inspired by other similar ideas, we asked the councilit could be included in the design to celebrate our gorgeous seafront.“We can’t wait to see it full of plants.”A council spokesperson said: “We were given a small boat and it has been requested that this is incorporated into the beds at the start of the promenade.“It has been decided that, rather than have three small beds, one larger bed will be created and we look forward to the creation of a display which will be enjoyed by visitors and local people alike."The boat was gted by an inidual and this was brought to our attention through contacts within Fisherrow Harbour and Seafront Association, which comprises the yacht club, Eskmuthe Rowing Club and other groups.”

title: pavement-outside-dunbar-primary-school-widened-holidays
story: Work will take place on Dunbar’s Countess Road, outside the John Muir campus of Dunbar Primary School, beginning on Monday.Councillor John McMillan, East Lothian Council’s spokesman for economic development and transportation, told the Courier that a consultation had taken place towards the end of last year, with the overwhelming majority of those taking part in the consultation in favour of the changes to the footpath.He said: “The Spaces for People programme in  funded temporary measures to create additional room for social distancing in our towns.“As the pandemic recedes, we are learning from our experiences of how public spaces were used over the last few years and we are considering which of these provided sufficient benefit to make permanent.“One such scheme was the widening of footways along Countess Road in Dunbar to make space for children going to school.“The online consultation in November last year found that  per cent of respondents were in favour of keeping or enhancing the section to the west of the crossing, and  per cent supported keeping or extending the one to the east.“However, it is recognised that the bolt-down bollards currently in place on the eastern side have caused some dficulties for firefighters accessing the station and these will be removed until an appropriate permanent scheme can be designed.”The works, which are expected to last a week, are dependent on the weather.

title: busy-programme-classical-music-coming-brunton
story: After a three-year break, the theatre welcomes back the Royal Scottish National Orchestra for a matinee performance on Sunday, March , at pm.Its musicians will present Tchaikovsky’s Symphony No. in E Minor. Also on the programme are Hensel’s Overture in C Major and Weber’s Andante and Hungarian Rondo.The Brunton’s lunchtime classical series enables audiences, with soup and a sandwich at noon in the upstairs bar, followed by an hour long recital in Venue  from pm, is continuing.The recitals include acclaimed Jordanian-Palestinian piano virtuoso Iyad Sughayer this Tuesday He will play a piano sonata by Haydn and music by Liszt, as well as Phoebé by Mel Bonis. Sibelius’s Impromptus will also be performed.March , sees afor accordionist Ryan Corbett.There is the chance to hear Trio Doyenne on April .Tickets for all performances are available online at thebrunton or by calling   .

title: dragons-den-everything-need-know
story: Sheila Hogan appears on BBC’s popular reality TV show Dragons’ Den this evening .The founder of the UK’s leading digital legacy vault, Biscuit Tin, is from Dunbar and travelled to Manchester for the once-in-a-letime opportunity.Tune in tonight to see how she got on.Through Biscuit Tin, the ‘deathtech’ entrepreneur aims to plug a gap in the market of end-of-le planning and digital legacy.The grandmother-of-two said: “Appearing on Dragons’ Den is a phenomenal experience preparing and pitching to such a highprofile and massively successful group of businesspeople is daunting, yet exhilarating.“It has been a fantastic opportunity and enormous privilege for me and Biscuit Tin to be chosen for the show.“Through my journey to the Den, I have grown in ways I never imagined.“I have learnt so much due to the Dragons’ Den experience and I am more ready than ever to take Biscuit Tin to the next level.” Sheila is making her presentation to veterans Peter Jones, Deborah Meaden, Touker Suleyman and Sara Davies, and newcomer Steven Bartlett, a marketing guru who has made his debut this series. Sheila Hogan has appeared on BBC One programme Dragons Den Biscuit Tin was born following Sheila’s personal experience of closing down the lives of her parents.Armed with a biscuit tin of old papers, the -year-old discovered that the way ‘end of le’ is handled today is completely broken and needs to change.Biscuit Tin was created to empower and enable everyone to plan for their death and make the whole process easier for those left behind.The business enables the secure online storage and encryption of valuable, vital information, all in one place, which is released to those nominated when the time comes.This includes information such as account details, important documents, post-le wishes and memories. Dragons Den is broadcast on BBC One at pm. The episode will also be free to view on BBC iPlayer.

title: east-lothian-businesses-top-uk-spending-charts-since-start-covid-19-pandemic
story: Analysis conducted by the Financial Times showed that spending at local shops had risen . per cent since March .Online sales in the county have also risen over half, by . per cent, resulting in a net spending growth of . per cent.Martin Whitfield, MSP for South Scotland, said: “This analysis is really positive news for East Lothian.“It underlines the great resilience, adaptability and innovation of our high streets and how well retailers have responded to the unprecedented challenges they have faced since March .“This success was in part due to hard work undertaken by businesses, communities and the council pre-Covid, such as the launch of the East Lothian Gt Card in .“The growth in sales retailers have experienced as a result of lockdown and homeworking also gives them something to build on and I hope they’ll see continued success during the recovery period.”This was the largest increase in the UK, as Scottish regions dominated the list.The figures indicate that, with people working from home, they have been more likely to support local businesses.The figures also show a comparable decrease in spending in Edinburgh.With foreign travel restrictions also imposed, tourist spots across the county have benefited from additional local visitors.

title: nicola-sturgeon-new-update-announces-changes-rules-face-masks-schools
story: The First Minister revealed the changes today in the Scottish Parliament.She said: “We do not want to keep these in place any longer than necessary.“On Tuesday the education advisory subgroup met. It re-iterated that removal should be phased.”She said the requirement for face coverings in classrooms will be removed from February .Sturgeon added: “This change will reduce barriers to communication in classrooms.”She saidpupils still want to wear a mask after the change, they can.She added: “Any young person or staff member who wishes to still wear a face covering should be fully supported in doing so.”She said it will still be required to wear face coverings in communal areas outside classrooms after February .

title: happened-east-lothian-biscuit-tin-founder-appeared-dragons-den
story: Sheila Hogan, the founder of the digital legacy vault company Biscuit Tin, faced the Dragons on Thursday, February s episode. The former President of the Association of Scottish Businesswomen launched her company in October  following her own personal experience of losing her parents. The Dunbar entrepreneur aimed to plug a gap in the market and change how "end of le" planning is organised today.Sheila Hogan on Dragons Den. Credit: BBC The digital vault is designed to securely hold valuable information such as account details, important documents, post-le wishes and memories all in one convenient place. Deborah Meaden was particularly touched by the concept due to her own personal experience.Sadly, the Dragon s- including Peter Jones, Deborah Meaden, Touker Suleyman, Sara Davies and new Dragon Steven Bartlett - chose not to invest this time around. All investors wished the entrepreneur luck and Ms Hogan left the Den more motivated than ever.Walking away without an investment, the Biscuit Tin founder said: "The whole experience has been tremendous."The only thing she said that she took issue with is new Dragon Steven Bartletts concerns over her ability to compete and grow against bigger tech companies.                                                                                                    : Dragons Den cast net worth - See how much Steven Bartlett and the Dragons are worth: Where is BBC Dragons Den filmed in the UK                                                                                                     She left the Den, vowing: "I can build a tech company and I will" - Good luck Sheila!Since the filming of the hit BBC show, Ms Hoggan has secured more than six times the original investment she asked for in the Den from other sources.Speaking about her experience on the programme, she said:“Whilst I didn’t secure investment from the Dragons on the show, I’m delighted to say that since filming the episode, I have been able to secure investment from other investors who have recognised the huge potential of Biscuit Tin. The investment closed at just over six times what was asked of the Dragons’.The entrepreneur added: “I have absolutely no regrets – Dragons’ Den has been a phenomenal experience, and such a privilege to be part of. Preparing and pitching to such a high-profile and massively successful group of businesspeople was a fantastic opportunity for me and Biscuit Tin."I have given consideration to all the Dragons’ comments, and it has made me even more passionate and determined to fulfil the mission, transform the way we handle end of le and make Biscuit Tin a household global brand to be proud of.”Dragons Den airs at  pm on Thursdays on BBC One.

title: plans-net-zero-flats-replace-bungalow-gullane-criticised-community-council
story: Gullane Area Community Council has asked East Lothian Council to refuse planning permission for the flats, describing the new build as “over-dominant”.The proposal by Edinburgh-based BY Developments Ltd would see the bungalow on Gullane Main Street demolished and replaced by a passivhaus building containing four three-bedroom flats.In a letter to the local authority, the community council said that while it did not object to the idea of flats on the site, the current proposals were too big and it added that the design appeared to include windows which were just one metre from neighbouring houses, adding: “It is hard to imagine this providing adequate lighting.”The proposals to replace the house, known as Glen Maree, with the flats aims to make it as sustainable as possible, with its design statement describing the residential development as “net zero”.It will include electric car charging points at a private parking area to the rear of the property, solar  and non-fossil fuel heating systems.The roof design has been created to ensure maximum solar exposure to support the flats and the design statement points out that easy access to public transport is also available to new residents of the flats.It adds: “This development makes efficient use of land, buildings and infrastructure by altering a previously developed plot of land in a town centre rather than a greenfield site on the town periphery, for example.“Industry-leading Scottish cross laminated timber is to form the superstructure, whilst Passivhaus principals of airtightness, heat recovery and solar gain are to be employed to create very efficient, low-energy dwellings.“We believe this strategy will result in a very energy-efficient use of the plot, with the four new apartments using less energy than the existing building.“We intend to create an exemplar development that demonstrates sustainability without compromising design quality.”The design statement adds that the site itself is not in the Gullane Conservation Area but “on the periphery” of it.Despite plans to position the new building eight metres back from the Main Street pavement with a large front garden area, the community council said that the design did not fit the site.It said: “We have no issue with the general principle of creating flatted accommodation on the site.“The particular choice of design, creating four substantial flats across three floors rather than the two of the neighbouring houses, does appear to be over-dominant in scale.“Eventhe building were able to be set slightly further back this effect could be diminished, but the site appears not to lend itself to this.”The application is available to view on the council planning portal.

title: east-lothian-gift-card-scheme-saw-sales-rocket-first-pandemic-christmas
story: The East Lothian Gt Card has become the seventh best selling area card produced by its suppliers in the UK.Launched in late , it offers people the chance to buy cards which can be used in local shops and businesses.A new report has revealed that the card has seen more than £, spent for use in local businesses since its launch, with more than £, bought to spend between October and December .Councillor John McMillan, economic development spokesperson for East Lothian Council, said that the success of the card had made it the seventh best performer in the UK for the supplier.He said: “It’s fantastic to see the East Lothian Gt Card proving so popular as it encourages use of our ied local businesses.“It’s more important than ever to support local traders as they recover from the effects of the pandemic.”The report, which has figures for the number of cards bought from October  to March last year, found that the average amount spent on the cards was £..The gt card was launched by East Lothian Investments on behalf of the local authority as a year-round offer following the success of the council’s Christmas shop local campaign, which had run for a decade.Hundreds of cards were sold during its first two years however, the report has revealed that between October and December , , cards were sold, with an average spend of more than £ each.Mr McMillan said: “While we don’t have final quarter figures yet for , we expect these to show very healthy sales again and we are seventh in the UK in terms of area gt card sales operated by our supplier.“We also know from recent research published in the Financial Times that East Lothian people supported their local traders more than any other UK local authority area during the lockdowns, which is testament to the quality of local businesses and the strong community spirit we have in East Lothian.“The gt card is a great way to support and encourage that ethos.”About  local businesses have signed up to accept the gt card in their stores, with no business charges applied to them.Pet shop owner Fiona Veerman said that the card had been a boost for local traders who were battling against online retailers.Fiona, who runs Veerman’s Pets  Co in Tranent, said: “We have always welcomed all customers into the shop with a smile, and we feel that this is especially important today as high streets up and down the country struggle to compete with online giants and out-of-town shopping centres.“We have been involved with the East Lothian Gt Card scheme from the outset, as it was created specically to encourage customers to think locally.“This is very important to us, as we also live in Tranent and know that money spent locally stays in the community.”No figures are available for the current financial year yet however, the report, which goes to the council’s audit and governance committee next week, reveals that East Lothian Investments is now looking into a way to provide the cards digitally in the future.

title: get-covid-test-kits-east-lothian
story: Mobile units are travelling all around East Lothian in the coming days to make testing kits more accessible for locals.No appointment is required to visit these sites, but kits will be available subject to availability.The schedule and location of these pop-ups are as follows:Friday,  February• North Berwick Sports Centre • Brunton Hall, Musselburgh Monday,  February• Port Seton Centre • Prestonpans Community Centre Tuesday,  February• The Original Factory Shop, Tranent • North Berwick Sports Centre Wednesday,  February• Haddington Corn Exchange Thursday,  February• Dunbar Garden Centre • Musselburgh Library Friday,  February• Tesco supermarket, Musselburgh • Brunton Hall, Musselburgh Monday,  February• Port Seton Centre • Prestonpans Community Centre Tuesday,  February• The Original Factory Shop, Tranent • North Berwick Sports Centre Wednesday,  February• Haddington Corn Exchange Thursday,  February• Dunbar Garden Centre • Musselburgh Library Friday,  February• Tesco supermarket, Musselburgh • Brunton Hall, Musselburgh Mobile testing units offering PCR tests will still be operating and will be open from am to pm.Residents should note that these mobile sites will not be visiting Meadowmill this Saturday and Sunday .Booking for these sites is not required but appointments are subject to availability.The mobile PCR tests will be available at the following locations:Friday,  February• Dunbar Leisure Pool• Loch Centre, Tranent• John Muir House, HaddingtonSaturday,  February Sunday,  February• Dunbar Leisure Pool• Loch Centre, TranentMonday, Friday,  February• Dunbar Leisure Pool• Loch Centre, Tranent• John Muir House, HaddingtonSaturday,  February Sunday,  February• Dunbar Leisure Pool• Loch Centre, TranentThe primary East Lothian test centre at Stoneyhill Community Centre in Musselburgh will also continue to operate and is open from am to pm Monday to Friday.Lateral flow test kits will also be available for collection at this site and no booking is required.

title: waterstones-reveals-childrens-book-prize-2022-shortlist---buy
story: books have been nominated across three categories from younger and older readers to illustrated books.Each category winner will take home a staggering £, pize.While one of the three will also be named Children’s Book of the Year will receive a further £,.Florentyna Martin, Waterstones Head of Children’s, said this year’s shortlist has been chosen to “inspire readers” in an increasingly uncertain world.A family reading a book together. Credit: Canva Ms Martin said: “Offering ied perspectives on themes of belonging and identity, the shortlisted books invite young readers to find comfort in familiar communities, discover engaging new worlds, or adventure to the unknown, all whilst being guided by unique, le-changing and relatable characters.”The winners will be announced at a ceremony on March .Front Desk - Kelly YangFront Desk is inspired by the Parachutes authors, Kelly Yang, own childhood.The story follows Mia and her motel-based Chinese immigrant family.Waterstones describes Yangs new book as an "irresistibly charming novel".It will cost you £. via the Waterstones website.Bumble And Snug And The Angry Pirates - Mark BradleyThe first comic book to make the shortlist, Bumble And Snug And The Angry Pirates shares lessons about friendship and controlling your anger.The book retailer describes it as a "freewheeling, superbly silly graphic novel" that tells the story of "two loveable Bugbops attempting to evade a horde of mad marauders."Waterstones recommends the comic book to fans of Dog Man and Bunny vs Monkey. The book is available for £. and can be purchased via the Waterstones website.A child reading a picture book with their parent. Credit: Canva Firekeeper’s Daughter - Angeline BoulleyAngeline Boulleys thrilling novel follows the le of a young Native American woman as she deals with dficult questions about community, corruption, and identity.Waterstones has dubbed the thriller a "gripping and brilliantly nuanced debut".You can pick up an exclusive signed bookplate edition of the novel which has a sprayed edge in one of three colours for £. from Waterstones.Or you can also take home a standard edition for the same price on the Waterstones website.Grandad’s Camper - Harry WoodgateWaterstones characterises Grandads Camper as "delightfully colourful and carrying a warm, positive message of inclusion and love".The story follows a grandad who tells his granddaughter about the travel adventures he used to have in his youth with Gramps.It was also A School Library Journal Best Book of  and is the book retailers pick for a Fathers Day present for Grandad this year.Grandads camper could be yours for £. via the Waterstones website.The Childrens book that was named Childrens Book of the Year in  was A Kind of Spark by Elle McNicol.A Kind of Spark - Ellie McNicolThe book retailer described McNicols novel as "beautully judged and peppered with wit and compassion", making it "truly inspirational reading".It follows the le of -year-old Addie as she campaigns for a memorial in memory of the witch trials that took place in her Scottish hometown.It won the Blue Peter Prize for Best Story in  and there is an exclusive edition available which contains a letter from Elle to her younger self and the first chapter of her next book Show Us Who You Are.Pick up a copy for £. via the Waterstones website.

title: atg-tickets-2-1-tickets-hairspray-edinburgh-playhouse-march
story: UK Theatres Love Your Local Theatre campaign means that when you buy a ticket for one of the below shows, you get a free ticket courtesy of The National Lottery.It is subsidising over , tickets at theatres across the UK as a thank you to National Lottery players for the £ million they raise each week for good causes - including the arts and theatre.The promotion is available to anyone who plays the National Lottery and has a National Lottery product. The National Lottery funded Love Your Local Theatre campaign is now open for booking! Show your support for our theatres with this brilliant new offer. It’s first come first served, so don’t miss out! https:t.co izmJwow pic PkpXhUIt is hoped that this initiative will encourage people to support their local theatres as they try to recover from the impact of the coronavirus pandemic.                                                                                                          : West End shows coming to the Edinburgh Playhouse - How to buy tickets: BBC One Big Night Of Musicals - How to buy tickets to all shows featured                                                                                                          class"instagram-media"data-instgrm-captioneddata-instgrm-permalink"https:www.instagram p CZhCgbMwpK  utm_sourceig_embedutm_campaignloading utm_sourceig_embedutm_campaignloading"data-instgrm-version""style"background: #fffborder: border-radius: pxbox-shadow:   px  rgba,  px px  rgbamargin: pxmax-width: pxmin-width: pxpadding: width: .%width: -webkit-calcwidth: calc"href"https:www.instagram p CZhCgbMwpK  utm_sourceig_embedutm_campaignloading utm_sourceig_embedutm_campaignloading"style"background: #ffffffline-height: padding:  text-align: centertext-decoration: nonewidth: %"target"_blank"style"background-color: #fffborder-radius: %flex-grow: height: pxmargin-right: pxwidth: px"style"display: flexflex-direction: columnflex-grow: justy-content: center"style"background-color: #fffborder-radius: pxflex-grow: height: pxmargin-bottom: pxwidth: px"style"background-color: #fffborder-radius: pxflex-grow: height: pxwidth: px"style"display: block height: px margin:  auto px width: px"width"px""px"viewBox"   "version"."xmlns"https:www.w.org  svg"xmlns:xlink"https:www.w.org  xlink"" fill"#"d"M.,.
